H0.text: who is in charge of new issues not mentioned in the constitution. The Supreme Court

H1.text: who is in charge of new issues not mentioned in the constitution. The President

H2.text: who is in charge of new issues not mentioned in the constitution. The Federal Judiciary

H3.text: who is in charge of new issues not mentioned in the constitution. Congress

A4.text: John Marshall in Virginia, James Wilson in Pennsylvania and Oliver Ellsworth of Connecticut all argued for Supreme Court judicial review of acts of state legislature.

A5.text: A limited constitution can be preserved in practice no other way than through courts which can declare void any legislation contrary to the Constitution.

A6.text: In the United States, federal and state courts (at all levels, both appellate and trial) are able to review and declare the 'constitutionality', or agreement with the Constitution (or lack thereof) of legislation by a process of judicial interpretation that is relevant to any case properly within their jurisdiction.

A7.text: In American legal language, 'judicial review' refers primarily to the adjudication of the constitutionality of statutes, especially by the Supreme Court of the United States.

A8.text: Many of the Founding Fathers accepted the notion of judicial review; in Federalist No. 78, Alexander Hamilton wrote: 'A Constitution is, in fact, and must be regarded by the judges, as a fundamental law. It therefore belongs to them to ascertain its meaning, and the meaning of any particular act proceeding from the legislative body.'

A9.text: The power of judiciary to overturn laws and executive actions it determines are unlawful or unconstitutional is a well-established precedent.

A10.text: Congress also has implied powers derived from the Constitution's Necessary and Proper Clause.

A11.text: The Constitution's Necessary and Proper Clause permits Congress to 'make all laws which shall be necessary and proper for carrying into Execution the foregoing Powers...'
